title: A Big Tech encore and Twitter showdown will shape biggest week of earnings season; Earnings Watch: Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Meta and Microsoft may not live up to the massive profit of last year, but they will still bring in plenty of cash as more than a third of the S&P 500 reports
text:
Google parent company Alphabet Inc. GOOGL GOOG, Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, Apple Inc. AAPL, Facebook parent company Meta Platforms Inc. FBand Microsoft Corp. MSFTcollectively put up profit and revenue in 2021 that more closely resemble a national gross domestic product than the work of a quintet of companies. With $320 billion in profit and $1.4 trillion in sales in a calendar year that included the worst inflation in the U.S. in four decades and an ongoing pandemic, Big Tech helped drive the S&P 500 index SPXto profit levels the world has never seen.

That boom could be at an end, however, a factor in the first quarter's tech-stock reversal. Only Microsoft is expected to appreciably increase profit from the same quarter a year ago when the five companies report earnings this week, though its $1.6 billion profit increase could paper over the decreases analysts expect for the others.

If profit actually falls, of course; these companies have been destroying expectations for the length of the pandemic. Google is an extreme example — the search giant has beaten the consensus earnings estimate in seven consecutive quarters, and by double-digit percentages each time, according to FactSet. Amazon has beaten profit estimates in six those seven quarters, twice by more than 500%, including last quarter's 668.2% surprise that was driven by Rivian Automotive Inc. RIVN.

Alphabet earnings preview: Amid a storm in tech sector, Google is staying relatively dry and happy

The biggest decline is expected to come from Facebook, which missed expectations three months ago for the first time during the pandemic and issued a forecast that sent investors fleeing. The social-media company's executives have warned of storms and arrived at earnings time dry and profitable before, but this time is expected to be different thanks to changes to Apple's mobile operating system.

Meta Platforms earnings preview: Facebook's meh year 'could get better … it just isn't'

Apple has also surpassed earnings expectations for the entire pandemic, and is expected to bring in more than $23 billion in profit, in-line with the same quarter a year ago. Wall Street will have its eyes more on the money coming its way this year than the black ink in Apple's ledger, however, as this quarter is always Tim Cook's cash giveaway.

Apple earnings preview: Tim Cook gave investors more than $100 billion last year — how much more is coming?

The five Big Tech companies will be the marquee highlights of the afternoon earnings parade this week, with Google and Microsoft reporting Tuesday, Facebook on Wednesday and Apple joining Amazon on Thursday. They will be far from alone, however: There are 175 S&P 500 companies expected to report before the market opens on Friday, 35% of the index, while 13 of the 30 Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIAcomponents are on the docket.

The calls to put on your calendar

* Twitter Inc. Twitter TWTR is decidedly not a Big Tech company — the social-media service reported as much revenue last year as Alphabet collects in about a week — but it has been in a big spotlight of late. The drama of Tesla Inc. TSLAChief Executive Elon Musk's bid for the company looks like it will continue to develop right up until the company reports earnings ahead of the bell Thursday morning, so expect some fireworks when CEO Parag Agrawal steps to the microphone in only his second earnings call since taking over from Jack Dorsey.

* Spotify Inc. Spotify SPOT had last season's "earnings call in the midst of controversy," and executives suggested that subscriptions would suffer in the first quarter, while denying that it was because of calls to boycott the streaming service to protest "The Joe Rogan Experience" podcast. On Wednesday morning, they will return to reveal how many subscribers were gained or lost, and update what they think is the cause for the shift.

The numbers to watch

* Intel Corp.'s margins. Intel INTC has faced pressure from Wall Street on its contracting margins, but CEO Patrick Gelsinger has stood tall to demand extra spending on manufacturing to combat the changing dynamics of the semiconductor industry. The latest battle between Gelsinger's grand ambitions and investors' desire to soak up dividends and stock buybacks will take place Thursday afternoon.

* PayPal Holdings Corp.'s active users. PayPal PYPLstock had the worst quarter in its history after the online-payments company predicted that massive user growth would slow down this year three months ago. The stock slide has yet to dissipate, so executives will either need to beat their own downbeat expectations or find a silver lining to offer Wall Street on Wednesday afternoon.

A Big Tech encore and Twitter showdown will shape biggest week of earnings season
